Ensuring Company-Wide Messaging is consistently applied across departments.  Often it feels as though messaging goes through a game of telephone from the Executive group to lower level staff.  Some pieces of the message get applied but often differently than another group.
The Corprorate/ Adiminstartive culture fight change and does not share information or knowedge.
Thinking through the downstream impacts of various decisions and ensuring all stakeholders are considered.
What the shifting of complexity from restaurants to staff will impact.

Simply making a decision and following through on it. Often times we don't make a decision at all so we just keep doing what we have been doing up to that point.  Or at the first sign of trouble or concern we revert back to the "old way" of doing things because this was the "wrong" decision
Doing more market research and competitor analysis around our shared challenge on advancing market ecosystems

Chick-fil-A needs to improve at decisions where there are multiple good/acceptable options (i.e., Chick-fil-A sometimes hesitates unnecessarily at trying to make the "perfect" decision when there are multiple "good" options to choose from which will all get the job done).

Decisions on how we work. We either need corner stones, and no days, or a day minimum in the office for work, but having both/neither is very confusing and leads to inconsistency in application and confusion of what is expected. Is it results, is it relationships? Does sitting at 5200 make my productive output better or worse, or is relationship building something that is measured with productive output too?
How to provide employees options for receiving more pay or other benefits if they opt out of the health insurance benefits.
Decisions involving leadership changes could be communicated sooner.

Understanding the impact of new initiatives on various teams - e.g. the roll out of new, complex initiatives weighs down teams that are already at full capacity. Often the teams that are impacted have no input or say into the decisions but have to take on the additional work regardless.

Long term visions for the company.  This may be more of a request than a "needs improvement" comment.  I would like to know how big a footprint we are looking to have over the next 5-10 years; both internationally and domestically.

Leadership promotion. Not everyone is fit to lead a team. There needs to be a balance between people/interpersonal skills and technical skills. Having too much of one or the other, does not a great leader make. How can one make decisions and attempt to advocate on my behalf if they don't truly understand my work?

DE&I in hiring/promotions - it is very obvious that DE&I has not been top of mind for the past few years within CFA. Even after this last year, I do not see things changing right away. Tax leadership is often silent when it comes to DE&I discussions. It is also discouraging to look at the org chart for Tax Leadership.
Take a good look at leadership and why there is no color diversity in some areas of the company.
Improving on having quicker hiring process and work with contractors to be more valuable.
I do no think there is anything need to improve at this point.
Chick-fil-A needs to improve upon the make-up of middle management and other top leaders.

Diversity of thought when selecting leaders. Too often people with the strongest technical background are selected as leaders. These individuals sometimes do not have the soft skills to be a leader or ever develop into an effective one.

The Operator model needs to adapt and change to the increasing complexity of the business and resource constraint. What Truett envisioned service to Operators to be in the 1970s is not the same as it is in 2021. The Operators are leading multi million $ businesses with 50+ team members.  They can handle some of the business/non chicken requirements of the business like various accounting services.
Better people need to be hired
Choosing to let poor performers  (in one way or another) stay on - there is no performance management for poor performers.
Reorganization decisions.  I think reorganizations happen way to often and it's a culture killer when you have to learn and build a relationship with a new leader every couple of years.
Decisions that "must" have input from a variety of people.  These are done too slowly.
Trade-off Decisions (doing this and not that)

Promotion for lower levels - trust people leaders, waste of resources to "convince" Total Rewards.  Total Rewards not consistent in talk versus action.  For example, skipping levels, inconsistent levels between departments, inconsistent application of level requirements.
Staff Facing (lack of coordination and understanding of downflow impacts)

Chick-fil-A is not as unique as we make it out to be.  We too often accommodate special circumstances or accommodations instead of pushing for consistent decisions.  For example, "This is a unique situation and we need to handle the situation in this manner.  It is 'one off.'"
How can we focus on a balanced appreciation for results and relationships without overly focusing on surface-level characteristics?
Sometimes decisions that help Operators and Restaurants are made very quickly and those supporting the work are left to figure it out in a tight timeframe.
Explain org changes better, how they trickle down.
Decisions on implementation time frames are at times unrealistic and place extreme demands on staff.
Thinking as if we are still a small company.
the ability for autonomy for lower down decisions. I feel like I am micromanaged when it comes to small things!
Flexibility for unknown circumstances from the on-set and not months later.
Contractual Agreements - speed from creation to execution
Decisions that impact the organization as a whole (back to the office)
Hiring individuals that specialize in the new works we're rolling out as opposed to just shifting those that are already on staff based on the fact that they know the culture of CFA.
allowing jeans to be included in dress casual

My department is lacking in strong leadership and direction.  There is so much work to be done that my people leader seems stuck and is too busy working on the work instead of leading me and my team mates to accomplish the work.

I think we could also stand to improve decisions around headcount.  I know we're doing our best to optimize what we have and improve systems so we don't need as many people, but some departments are drowning in work and utilizing contractors instead of staff.  That has to be expensive.  Plus, it's on work that doesn't go away.  It seems as if there is more attention paid to those departments that directly support Operators, which I do understand.  However, if we keep growing those groups and not the staff that support all of us, then we're still in a deficit.
Trendy decisions based on feedback that slightly go against our values/goals.
We don't look to consolidate functions across the business.  We have many staff across the business doing similar functions (e.g. purchasing, sourcing, project mgmt)
Individual team restructuring and related position re-leveling
How to contract with software suppliers
What products to roll out to the business
slow on implementing needs on corporate side
Continuing to engage talent on a personal level as we get bigger.

We need to have a framework for reference for cross-functional work that is not project-based with a lead facilitator to provide clarity as to who has the "D" when questions/issues come up and what are there qualifications that would align the "D" to a certain level of leadership.  We currently have a culture of consensus  and CFA Nice where staff tend to hesitate to step out and call the "D".

Job Levels. In the most recent re-org, I noticed Employee A left a role at one level and Employee B was promoted to THAT SPECIFIC ROLE but leveled beneath where Employee A had been. Same job, different level. This type of thing erodes the trust staff has placed in the talent management system. We were told job levels were to be determined entirely by the job itself (rather than the person), but in practice, that is not true.
Decisions where there isn't a single person/group accountable (i.e. staff headcount)
Deciding to implement projects BEFORE having required employees in place to do the work.
tension/who owns the decision type decisions.  too collaborative.  have to get 8 people to say yes to something and if one person says no it is a no.

CFA seems to me to be a consensus driven organization. I feel like we wait until everyone agrees before we move forward on an endeavor instead of getting the right level of authority at the table for decision making.
Standardization (Guidelines as well as rules) regarding documents and the way we work.

what does stewardship look like from an accountability perspective? We all want to be good stewards of what's been entrusted to us, but we have different ideas for what that looks like, because accountability at an enterprise level is not clear.

I think they need to re-think the goal to have staff work in the office a set average number of days.  It really needs to be up to the staff member to determine where they can get their work done in the most efficient manner.
Contractor involvement, EX:  when a contractor can / can't be included.  Culturally it is difficult to not treat them as all other staff.

Reporting- sometimes I think we are such a 'Dashboard' heavy company that we lose sight of what value or key decisions are being derived from a Dashboard; in other words, how does the input that goes into creating a Dashboard weigh relative to the value output (are people actually using the Dashboard?)
Improve Hiring practice at a faster pace
Lack of response in staff surveys that say many feel they don't have time for personal development in current state of work.
Promotions - decisions are not consistent and take too long.
Growth.  How can we scale properly for growth across the business in every area?

Hiring staff faster.  It takes an act of Congress to even get staff approved. I can appreciate that lean mentality to prevent unnecessary hires, but there are so many interviewers involved, it takes forever to get the position filled. Talent is struggling to catch up from Covid. They need help to get staffing needs filled.
Decisions regarding the titling structure and levels. There is much confusion surrounding promotion and moving to the next level.
Decisions made around  communication to be sent out. Communication gets scrutinized vigorously, and at several levels of the hierarchy.
Staff-related decisions. For example, more notice of exact dates for required staff events.

Decisions that are highly cross-functional is another area where improvement is needed.  This is a difficult area since it may impact many areas which can create slow-down and many different opinions.

JCCC is SUCH an incredible benefit to employees and I know that it is one of the biggest pulls for talent recruiting at CFA. However, now that we are (finally!) being given the option to work from home for a majority of the time (and avoid horrible traffic and a long commute-yay!), many of us would prefer a childcare stipend to put our children in a daycare that is close to our home. This would avoid us having our children in the car for 1.5+ hours every single day to get them to/from daycare and would allow parents to actually take advantage of the WFH opportunity.
Technology- decision to provide necessary technology for returning to the Support Center, such as double monitors and video conferencing in all meeting rooms
CFA needs to cast vision and inspire throughout all levels of leadership

People hiring. The hiring process is so long that we have open positions to fill for months on end. This adds to the workload of everyone else on the job and can lead to burnout. If adequate resources were invested in the hiring process for each individual, we could move through the stages much faster.

Generally speaking there is a need to clarify decision ownership where staff underneath the EC meet often with lack of clarity. Possibly there could be a clearer process for how escalation happens should agreement not end up being possible.

Tension between rapid "scrappy" tools and ability to scale and automate. Neither is bad on it's own, but we sometimes act like there aren't tensions and tradeoffs to be made.  Which do we want? What tradeoffs are we willing to accept because of that?  For example, if we want speed and scrappy tools for a new entity, we'll need more headcount because those tools are manual and take man hours to support.  If we want ability to build a system or tool or process that scales with a large multi-national enterprise, we need to trust those closest to the work to estimate the resources and timeline options available.
Define when to stop a project or body of work
People who do not travel making decisions for people who do travel.   Example:  The expense app.  It is terrible.  CWT, I know we save money but it is terrible.

Chick-fil-A should expand the Enterprise Innovation team so that all departments at the Support Center are focused on building a culture of innovation.  An innovation process will help us execute business decisions faster and more efficiently.  A culture of innovation will help us see where the puck needs to go (how guests want to be served conveniently, quickly and safely) rather than where the puck is going (not letting the QSR industry show where the puck is going).
Go all in with data adoption and tech resources. It has seemingly taken too long to begin to heavily incorporate data into out decision making and into Operators' hands.
Embracing more progressive changes rather than a bias towards what we've done in the past.  Partly due to middle management who's conservative.

Making changes in leadership for the sake of making decisions.  Because someone is "good at their job" doesn't automatically mean they will be a good leader.  These decisions need to be intentional and leadership development needs to be required (internal and external).
COVID vaccination mandates - It is not a sustainable practice to get tested weekly if we are not even coming into work on the daily or travel often for work.

Continue to improve Operator Selection to continue finding potential Operator with appropriate business acumen to run increasingly fast-paced, complex, and rapidly growing businesses (currently, I think we do a great job with selection, yet there's opportunity to raise the bar with the business acumen we expect for successful Operators, without sacrificing the critical focus on character and cultural fit)
At what level decisions should be made
Posting new jobs after headcount approval.

It sometimes feels as if promotions of some are rushed, while others may be overlooked. Maybe this is a misevaluation of talent? I?ve seen this happen some in my area where some people seem to be on a fast track (even if they show signs of not being prepared or not able to handle the extra responsibilities), while others are not even given opportunities for growth.
Brand expansion decisions (more so speed than quality of decision)

Talent / hiring decisions. CFA Inc is growing at an unbelievable rate, and sometimes it feels as though arduous Talent processes slow down hiring / recruiting decisions which puts a strain on teams that need more people.
Ownership of project work can be more collaborative and reduce silos and parallel redundancies of projects
Promotion process & career paths long term (internal moves)

Decisions such as International and Beyond The Restaurant has pulled resources and they are not always replaced making it harder to support Operators. Additional staff that are not on these teams, are being pulled to support them. This is not sustainable.

While it is good to encourage people to use their PTO, I wish we could consider allowing more to roll over and be paid out when you retire or at end of each year.  It seems like many people plan to use theirs but find they end up having to work some during the time they had planned to be off.

While I am encouraged by the changes that have been made, we still have some work to do with diversity in the organization.  With the recent restructure, I was hoping to see the promotion of an African American female into a VP position.  There are currently no black women at that level, though we have several at the Executive Director level.
Not pushing the vaccine as the only option for "COVID"

I have witnessed my department struggle making good decisions regarding mid-level leadership - promoting tenure over talent and putting the careers of young talent in the hands of questionable leaders.

Growth at times has felt prioritized over doing the job well. I understand getting ahead of the curve, but I don't think our competitors will be anywhere near the curve with the staffing issues.
DE&I Education as a requirement, currently it is not required, but other trainings are that seem in a similar vein

In our group, we often spend WAY too much time adding ad hoc work that distracts from the main plan. It's important work, but it obviously wasn't important enough to make it into the plan. It's when we add all this other work that we lack the focus needed to drive the core business plan items for our individual group forward with the needed speed.
People Leader budgets.   The autonomy to surprise and delight Team Members.

With other companies moving towards more flexible working options, I believe we are losing top tier talent that otherwise would choose to work for us if we had more flexible WFH options. I understand that there is a need for employees to be in person for certain events but having employees that live out of state for legit reasons and then requiring that they pay their own way for travel seems a little crazy. At the end of the day, we should want the most qualified candidate in our roles and I believe a more flexible WFH policy could help achieve gaining/retaining great talent.
Reopening of the office in January.

Accurate level of placement when hiring and/or promoting. Example: If someone applies for a position, but they are more qualified to be in a different level, then they should be interviewed/hired for the level they qualify for. Also if they are hired into a level that they are overqualified for and should have been one level higher, they should have the option of skipping a promotion level to get to the right placement.

There is so little clarity on what is required of this halted OSHA mandate.  If someone refuses to get vaccinated, get tested, or wear a mask, do they just work virtually until the environment becomes inclusive again, or will they be fired?  If the latter, is CFA willing to lose a large group of people just because those employees decide to stand up to discrimination?

It seems like some decisions are made very slowly. For example I heard from many Operators at RPMS how much better it would be if their team could be paid weekly--especially considering the talent shortage crisis that many are struggling with. It sounded like it will be at least 3 years before this will be an option. Why can't we prioritize this more when it would be such a huge win for our restaurants?
Ones that impact multiple departments.  Often times too many opinions impact the speed at which a decision can be made.
people- people decisions in promotions and in internal moves
Allow staff to dress according to their day (who they interact with).  Casual, business casual, or business formal.

There are a lot of moving areas in the business right now and as much as I love the atrium talks to get updates, I feel like there are a lot of questions that go unanswered. I know not all questions can be answered during the live atrium talk, but a follow up would be greatly appreciated. I feel that this would make people feel heard and understood and provide more clarity.

clarity on expectations and priorities of the core business compared to strategic bets. If we had clarity sooner on priorities, we could circle back with leaders and resource better to meet those expectations. But currently we are STRUGGLING to meet all the expectations and pulls from so many strategic bets, initiatives and our own improvement processes/work.  For example, it was originally shared from the EC that individual teams will not be impacted by Int'l, and they were funding that work outside core/dept/big move work. But the reality is, many teams have had to hire people within their teams to keep up with the demand for Int'l with very little strategy shared and LOTS of wasted time with lack of communication on decisions and what decisions mean or after a decision was made, individual teams had to make a lot of changes to meet that decision/expectation (causing lots of stress and misaligned priorities for cross-functional work). It's very hard
Decisions on promotions need to be better explained.  I am unclear as to why some people get promoted quickly and others don't.

I think the new Talent Management System (TMS) has done some good things, but there is no denying that it has absolutely changed the dynamic and culture of our work environment. One downside is that I feel it encourages unhealthy individualism instead of organizational and team-spirit. More and more it seems like I bump into staff who I can tell are just in this for themselves. It has been a little disheartening. On the plus side, I like that we have more internal opportunity, but the new TMS model in conjunction with that opportunity has led to rewarding/incentivizing the wrong thing in my opinion. For example - as a staff member reaches level 9+, they stand to gain more financially by seeking a new role than they do to excel in their current role. What is the impact of that to the team and the organization?
Fewer meetings.  Many seem redundant and unnecessary.  Steals productive work time.
none that I know of based on the position that I am and the knowledge that I have.

How we are thinking about coming back to work on January 10th.  The Cornerstones/framework is a masked policy and the 10 days was not a CFA approach.  Sounds more like a mandate that other companies do...not CFA.
Personal responsibility with regard to health and safety.
support the need for change management
We have too much innovation happening within various areas of the business, competing for shared resources.

Stop decisions, such as decisions to stop, end, or cancel a certain body of work or project. We can let projects go on for too long, even when there is no hope for success.

Company-wide, shorter and fewer meetings should be encouraged. Meetings 1 hour or more should always be scheduled with 10 minutes detracted from the meeting time. Meetings 30 min or less should be scheduled with 5 min detracted from the meeting time. Thus, an hour meeting would be scheduled for 50 min and a 30 min meeting would be scheduled for 25. Back-to-back meetings lead to consistent lateness and burnout.
We need to be better at identifying roles and responsibilities early on in a project.

Instituting some sort of project management methodology into critical projects to ensure goals, scope of work, project teams, project milestones, etc. are carefully and clearly defined, and that Voice of Customer (whoever customers may be) is taken into account and is the primary input for solution development (let's not assume internally what solutions restaurants want).

Decisions related to investment in talent at lower levels.  Feels like nearly all intentional movement of people is done at director level or above (Michael Lage, Khalilah C, etc.). Style versus Substance.  We've become obsessed with Style.  It's not enough to have a strategy or idea.  It must be packaged with a hype video or world class presentation.  We need to focus more on results and execution.  Too many consultants running around 5200 Buffington Road.
Deciding success of pilots. We are really bad at calling something a failure and moving on.  We continue to pump money into it and spin the story.
Greater willingness to stop work that's not a priority
Need to add more process to business decisions
How do we decide what we need to work on for the future?
identifying effective leaders/managers within the company

Recognizing that culture can be maintained via virtual environment - allowing staff to work from home even more (reducing the 10 days/month required to be in the office).

I have been told that Operators receive a million emails daily.  So they may over look emails about certain items.  Everyone feels their area is most important and I understand that, but communication should be streamlined so that no emails or communication is over looked.
Allocating the right amount of talent to different areas of the business.
Being willing to train exciting employees in new areas of interest and giving them the opportunity to move up to higher levels.
Newer to the company so I don't have an example but based on the results things seem to handled well.

Aligning product quality to customer preference and across groups. (Menu, Quality, Restaurant)
Process Simplification - including the essential stakeholders involved on projects, signoffs, decisions, etc.
Organizational structure seems confusing thus defining who the actual decision maker is lost.

Keeping the Chick-fil-A culture, but allowing some flexibility in some areas like facial hair. It took so long to make the decision on facial hair! To go along with this, dressed-up jeans on Fridays would be awesome at the office :)
Tours of duty for senior leadership.  Just because someone is a "good leader" doesn't mean that they could/should lead in areas that require industry knowledge.
Decisions that protect the company from future risks.

At times it feels like leadership isn't listening to the challenges we are facing and they push new and exciting things (menu), instead of focusing on the core menu items that we are better able to control.

Speed of overall decision making - all too often, a "simple" decision has to be approved or reviewed by multiple teams of people that just seem to cause bottlenecks to the process of servicing the business and Operators.
The Work from Home stance could be clearer. We haven't heard anything on this in some time I feel like. Are we supposed to be coming back the 10 days a month in January?

Chick-fil-A seems to continue to prioritize new projects over core work. They promote and elevate those working on new projects, while those that are keeping the business going today while planning for the future, seem to be left in the dust. You have to focus on the future but you can't leave behind those who are working on the core business.
Identifying and understanding individual skill sets and how those best fit into an organization structure (short and long-term).

Resistance to change that is disguised as climbing with confidence and care. Absolutely want to climb with confidence and care, but need to be able to also make tough decisions that will make a difference quickly.

We need to honor deadlines set to stop development (on menu items and other projects as well) and move forward quickly and efficiently without making additional changes that affect potential delivery dates.

The timeline for a test/rollout/LTO should not be determine prior to getting lead times from suppliers.  We are pushing our suppliers to tight deadlines to a timeline that has already been set.  With supply issues, there are times that issues arise that are out of supplier's hands.

CFA needs to gain input from people who have been with the company at least a year or 2 on strategic big decisions rather than hiring in people at a high level with ideas, but don't understand the current business.

New menu or packaging decisions that don't free up capacity for operators or for supply chain. There's a functional hierarchy and new menu objectives tend to get pushed through without consideration for other functions or operator efficiency.

Internal people moves- when/how it happens- process of reorgs
Creative decisions within Marketing are overly collaborative.
People moves - this past re-org was really deflating to many.

Leadership: Chick-fil-A does not prepare leaders for how to best lead people and how their work gets done. We put people in leadership for a variety of reasons and many times they have not been given the tools/guidance/experience to truly lead a large team to productivity, satisfaction, empowerment, maximum results, etc.  Our leaders are generally great people, qualified and their intentions are all right and they have good ideas but there could be more support for them on processes, customer-oriented mindset, strategy/planning with data/metrics, as well as an understanding of workflow and decision frameworks to best empower/enable their teams. I also think there needs to be an opportunity for 360 feedback loop in Workday from their team members on improvement opportunities. We are growing so fast, we have talented people but we need to prepare our leaders for the workplace of the future; we still operate using older/more traditional work styles/methods.

Still too much consensus driven decision making which also decreases productivity. Its ingrained in our culture. Hopefully we can begin to trust one another to make the appropriate decision at the lowest level possible.
Decisions that can/could be made at the SME or team level

Time to make decisions - it sometimes takes too much time to make decisions (risk we miss opportunities or bring them to life rather slowly). Drivers:     Very consensus driven     Fragmented information systems so it takes a long time to gather information to support recommendations
Work that has cross functional implications - who has the 'D' when project scope changes create impacts in supporting departments?
Planning decisions that need multi-level approvals.

We need to improve our understanding of roles in decision making.  Where does the EC stop and functional officer begin? What is centralized versus decentralized? What does the People leader actually own in terms of decision-making?
Organization planning driving functions vs. functional planning driving organization planning.  Bubble up strategies are too silo'd and self serving and lack appropriate trade off discussions.
Some decisions should be made closer to the situation.  Empower those who have the most knowledge and experience versus escalating the decision to senior leaders
How do we manage shifting talent performance over time, especially in places where business may be outgrowing individuals in current role.
Decisions involving a shift from the status-quo
Decisions where there is a great deal of disagreement on what the right decision is.
calendars/scheduling- its gotten crazy trying to connect with people to move decisions forward

Chick-fil-A is an extremely influential business in Georgia. I would like to know that CFA is pushing back against current OSHA mandates (NOT Laws) that affect so many people. This is happening across the country and I've heard too many people comment that they can't believe CFA is folding. The mandates are inconsistent, contradicting and persecuting.  This is a decision I believe Chick-fil-A should choose to fight.
Allowing teams (staff) to make decisions rather than the top making decisions that don't require the top making the decision.
Staying true to who we are as a company and not caving to media or public scrutiny.
decisions regarding low performing employees. Poor behavior or performance is allowed to continue for long periods of time.

Re-organized again?  Reorganizing every year or 18 months is frustrating.  Feel like we take steps back in production and frankly the sense of belonging when we are moved around like pawns on a chess board.
Improve Staff Awareness of emergency process in the event a Support Center evacuation is necessary.

We need to figure out a way to help people understand the work of the different departments.  It would give others insight into the business and all the wonderful things we have to brag about (e.g. the way we work to create win-win partnerships with our suppliers).  It would help with cross-departmental projects and better equip staff to assist/direct Operators/Team Members.
Right place for people to be
Replacing too many "non-essential" workers with contractors.
Our current culture is encouraging micromanaging.
Processes for accomplishing work and gaining approval on work. It can end up wasting significant amounts of time when processes are not clear, overcomplicated, or convoluted.
I'm not sure I'm answering this correctly but I do wish Chick-fil-A leadership would consider a more casual work environment.
Make a decision on how will CFA, Inc. support Entities and what that will look like, operationally, financially, legal, culture, etc.

Decisions necessary to hold people or work accountable will probably always have some level of improvement needed. The abundance of grace offered at Chick-fil-A is admirable - and I have certainly been a recipient in my career. However, challenges occur when "grace" turns into lack of accountability. I have seen many times in my own department where an individual has been relocated to team after team in an attempt to "address" a problem, but the problem is truly never addressed. When this happens, not only does the work suffer, but team dynamics and individuals suffer as well. When an issue continues for an extended period of time, oe of the ripple affects is a perceived lack of support for those individuals picking up the slack or carrying the weight in the interim.

I was really disappointed that the Support Center Transformation work seemed to fall apart - overall there is poor communication or lack of rationale for when something is abandoned or morphed into something different.  This isn't so much about the decision-making process as it is about following a disciplined and transparent process of communicating/clarifying the conditions that precede or serve as impetus for a decision, then ensuring wide spread understanding of the solution, then creating accountability for the studying of the effects of the solution/decision, and creating systems of improvement.
My concern is not with the quality of the decisions but with how long it takes to make organization decisions.

Teaming approach - we have too many "leadership teams" and "cross-functional teams". Some are completely necessary, but too many teams are spun up and given the appearance of importance because "such and such a leader has commissioned us to solve this issue"
Getting clarity regarding stakeholder management - who has true decision rights vs input. If input but not your idea/way need to get better at living with it vs dissenting
Committing resources with existing partners - I.e., push contracts down closer to the work

Decisions that require organizational alignment around a process or procedure. When "principles" or "guardrails" are set that are then open for interpretation across teams and people, it can create translation confusion and therefore tension.

Consistency of practice and accountability -- particularly in roles that are Operator-facing, like Ops Leads. It seems like 100 different people in the job can do the "same" job 100 dramatically different ways. People definitely need freedom to create and tailor their roles, but a complete lack of consistency and accountability becomes a massive problem. This makes dealing with CFA much more unpredictable, much slower, more cumbersome, and WAY more difficult than it has to be.

We need to improve how decisions are made between agile teams and the bureaucratic parts of the business. Our leadership keeps pushing agile whether it fits or not. They expect us to be agile, but they do not use agile principles or the tools we are forced to use. Also, the leadership of our dept does not create a leadership structure that supports agility. This slows things way down when we have to have bureaucratic functional leaders interact with agile teams. It is also hard to change things because each person on the agile team has a different leader, so you have to get 4-5 leaders to agree and then take it to our dept leader. It is so slow. Also, functional leaders hire for what they want on their functional team versus the skills the agile team needs to do its work.

CFA needs to decide if we are running an agile business or scaling agile.  There are so many departments doing some version of agile and that's great but it gets messy when there are so many versions.  Also, its really difficult to be on an agile team when the leaders of your department are working in an agile framework.  It makes things difficult when functional leaders and Agile teams aren't aligned.

Decisions around changes in how we work appear to be made without input from those who are doing the work and who are impacted.  The execution of these types of decisions suffers when there is little focus on how the decisions support the broader company strategy.

The vision and strategy for career development is not clear leading me to believe their might not be one established which causes great concern.  People are looking for opportunities where they can grow - there doesn't appear to be a well thought out avenue for that. Is there a strategy or vision for this? Perhaps it needs to be published?

Functional/Department level decisions don't always level up to what we are saying are organizational priorities and tend to be what's trendy or what individual preferences are.  Strategies often change too quickly - usually based on re-structures which then prompts working on a new strategy for the department and creates a cycle where the employees never really know what the goal is because it is changing yearly.
Tactical decisions.  The leaders I work with want to make decisions on all of the tactical/operational decisions vs. staying in Strategic decisions that would impact the business 3 - 5 years out.

People Decisions - the same people  - the "Rock stars" are promoted, given stretch assignments, assigned to Strategic Bets and cross functional teams with very little transparency or reasoning. Staff are left wondering about the process - the procedural fairness and what feels like a "secret closed door" process amongst leaders and the Talent Consulting Team - what data is being used to inform these decisions aside from anecdotal data?

Supporting international growth. It is currently painful to stand up new countries. Clear, central decisions are hard to find and slow to materialize.  Its not always clear if decisions about the timing of launch, level of support, menu, equipment, and supply differences fully consider the downstream implications to our content development. It takes time to build, translate and publish content to prepare for launch. And it feels like a scramble every time.

The tremendous variety of ways people can be "working" but not getting anything done because of meetings, baby showers, workshops, lunch and learns, devotions, wellness hours.  Everyone talks about how busy they are, but it's very much the cause of all the distractions we have.

Group decisions at the department or sub-department level can also be improved by not involving as many people and get hung up on everyones consensus. However, this still needs transparency and communication of a decision that was made. Or if there's time on the front end, seek input from a wider audience, but at least clearly communicate the specific people who will be deciding and when.
When and how to return to in-person meetings.

Decisions around medical choices. For a long time there was one-sided messaging and lots of requests and even benefits provided to us when we got vaccinated. Medical choices are personal and private, and it was concerning to hear these messages and see the "benefits" that were being provided to those who complied, while simultaneously seeing the "penalties" for those who did not. Again, these kinds of medical choices are private, and while I am thankful to hear more messaging around choice and freedom to choose, it is concerning that there was a time when this was not truly the case. Requiring masks even now, when the threat of covid is so low and so many are now vaccinated, feels like an imposition on freedom of choice. This is compounded by the fact that the CDC only recommends masks, and only if unvaccinated. To have a requirement that everyone wear a mask feels restricting and is a cause for concern for me. It does not feel like care, it feels like fear.

Work being done. I don't understand why we have to ask permission to work on stuff when we have the capacity and the work needs to get done. In the L&D department work must be approved at the portfolio level and oftentimes the department work is not distributed in a balanced manor. There are teams that are swamped and other teams that are not doing much work because the work is not approved. It doesn't make sense. The people doing the work should be able to just do the work.

Continue tearing down silos - from my perspective each department continues to make their own decisions and frequently the work to make those decisions become reality falls on other teams who are also balancing other decisions. For example, the test and rollout calendar seems to have set dates before understanding the work of other departments to make those dates reality.

Definition of what "professionalism" looks like. It's not the "Mad Men" era. It's a new day and people can still perform their work and be professional wearing denim jeans. It's 2021 for goodness sakes.
Decisions for social trends can be too conservative but getting better (i.e. beards, tattoos, acceptable dress codes for restaurant and office attire).

Decisions in which puts more Staff in the field more often. Operators need help labor-wise and we as Staff need to 1) reconnect with Operators in there space 2) better understand new restaurant realities and 3) based on 1 and 2 influence our teams/work at the Support Center to better support Operator needs.
Not decision making per say but change management when decisions are made, especially at the department level and in communication between the Support Center and Operators

Politics. In L&D especially it seems like it's a popularity contest. They shut down people who share direct, fair, and honest opinions and feedback because it doesn't fit the mold. I've watched my mentors who are pioneers in the learning industry get shot down multiple times and it's incredibly discouraging. It has made me not share honest feedback because I've seen that every time that happens, leadership will do the opposite of what people recommend. I've always thought that they had their reasons that I'm just not seeing, but now that I've seen them use multiple people multiple times because those people are good at their jobs and then keep them stuck in their same positions with the only reason of "you're the only one who knows the content", is absurd to me. They don't let their people grow because they don't hire people who actually learn their role so all the work that people don't know and can't/aren't willing to do falls on the select few people who are actually wanting to work, learn, and grow. It is baffling that L&D leadership just ignores this issue and doesn't see it. Most of the extremely talented Learning Partners on the Learning Partner team have moved to different departments and L&D leadership says it's because the L&D department has helped them with their career goals, but for many of them, it's actually because the L&D department leadership doesn't reward their good work by helping them move around within the L&D department. I would love for my career to grow in learning because that's what I want to do, but if I want to grow and learn at Chick-fil-A, I'm realizing that I will probably need to look outside of the L&D department.

Staff Training. We need to do a better job of training and equipping people to perform well in their job, especially when the move to a new position is a stretch. Sometimes a stretch is appropriate but can still fail if the person is not prepared or equipped for the move, either before or during.

We need to develop a language around priority level and business impact when making decisions. At the moment, it seems that all decisions, especially those that may impact Operators, all carry the same level of priority. An example is recent decisions around Little Blue Menu that required resourcing or investment that have jumped ahead of or delayed decisions that affect much larger parts of the organization.
Leaders need to be comfortable with decisions made by those empowered to, and not backtrack with expectations that could derail progress made or change scope significantly.
Leadership succession lower than the EC level
Reducing complexity in the restaurant. I feel like this is talked about a lot, but it does not feel like there's action behind it.
The decision to move to "leveling" each role can make some in the bottom levels not feel important or worthy, especially for those who have been around a long time.

Tools and systems. It would be great for Chick-fil-A to continue to offer options and innovation while also streamlining systems. I have already seen such great strides with this (i.e. bluejeans, miro, Planview Leankit, workday, oracle, etc.) but it can get confusing as well.

Contingent Worker Policy:  I'm wondering if there is a better stance we could take regarding CW's.  The policy is to ensure that we draw a line between CW and staff.  However, there are many times when I believe we aren't caring for them fully because of these restrictions.  Example:  Christmas celebrations within a team.  Teams feel the need to either not have a team Christmas party OR have a separate one from the CW's that we work with day in/out.

What kind of company is CFA in the modern world? How focused are we on keeping and recruiting new and young talent?  This can get difficult with more traditional ways of working. How can we attract a diverse work force? How would that diverse work force help support international growth?

Better talent selection of middle managers. Read the research at https://hbr.org/2021/06/the-real-value-of-middle-managers. The inspiring quote is "The most effective ones are in possession of humane, sophisticated communications skills and the knack to mediate and find common grounds between actors at different levels in the organization." Too many times middle managers simply say the exact same thing as executive leadership and do not do the best job of finding common ground between levels in the organization.
Deciding to "add" deliverables, but not "delete" deliverables

amount of capital for reinvestments with our older Restaurants can take longer than expected, clear messaging to Operators sooner than later is appreciated and needed...even when it's a no.   Share this sooner vs. later to keep relationships strong.
Moving decision making further down the chain of command and making it clear who owns what decision.

Org/Re-org chart decisions, while certainly an element of a growing business, are still anxious seasons as Staff sense or guess at what is to come. Some of the wonder and concern is valid while mostly it is conjecture that creates tension for awhile. Most Staff have experienced these already, however, the looming of the next one can hover over Staff trying to determine their own next career move/trajectory. Sharing org decisions at the earliest and setting transition dates as soon as possible help 'rip the band-aid off' quickly.

Vendors and Contractors. Sometimes we jump to using outside resources for projects or teams when what we really need is a dedicated person to the work. Because of the rule that we use contractors for only 1 year at a time, we tend to hire people and onboard them only to have them leaving by the time they are really catching on. We then have to retrain more people. this is a very frustrating cycle.

Staff does not know when Operators are at the Support Center. When Operators are in classes, graduating or on site for meetings. Staff (especially new staff) could not feel connected to the Operators as we not making those connections. Staff may have no idea how many restaurants and where we are opening them up every Thursday.
Too much time if focused on individual team restructures and department mission statements.
Selection decisions - the staff selection process still seems very broken.

The process and time for the new remote worker policy was interesting. For months, the question was asked in multiple staff meetings and seemingly ignored. Once an announcement was made, it seems like there could have been more clarification. We learned during the pandemic that we can all do the work we do successfully and not be tied to a specific location. For myself, I would dream about moving approx 3 hours away to be able to serve my family better, but don't have a "reason" since I'm not married. In a small way, when the new policy was announced, I felt that family and culture matters, as long as it's in Atlanta.
Staffing in how it relates to the work load.  Quicker decisions on staffing needs for the business.
I think people decisions are largely left unexplained.
Align Communication/Projects where staff are knowledgeable about the daily business
Try to avoid having so many people speak into decisions

It is so hard to go from a small, Southern company to a large, global company. I have heard frustrations from both sides (Operator and Staff) as to where we stand. While our Corporate Purpose is the same, many interpret it differently. As an example, "to glorify God" means so many different things to so many. What does it mean to CFA as a company? Also, are we going global as a company to earn more and expand our footprint or to impact more global lives? Both?

utilizing staff in a more agile way. Seeing potential in poeple to serve in various area of the business and being able to quickly shifts goals based on business realities. Sometimes we get so "married" to an idea or goal, the business/operator's needs have shifted, but we're so invested (financially, head count, etc.) we keep going.  how might we equip staff members to be multi-demensional similar to a TM who is trained in both BOH and FOH? This I think would solve part of the "we need to hire so many people".  While our growth right now is great, in 5 years if we have doubled staff numbers, will we need all the specialized positions? Will we need 7000 staff if technology has eliminated some roles?  It's great we don't terminate, but out of all the decisions we are expediting/making fast, I am super surprised that offering full time jobs is what we are saying is an "emergency" and our greatest need.
I don't have any other examples

In my department in particular (not feeling as if I have confidence to make a statement across the organization), there is room to improve decisions around the kinds of systems and processes implemented - and how those are used across multiple teams. Many processes of workflows are done at an independent or singular level which leads to a lot of time spent on work that can be automated or simplified, a great amount of loss when a Staff moves to a new role and a new hire comes online, and a lot of spending that can be consolidated and efficiencies created.
Career management- managing SC Staff's career expectations and aspirations.
Honestly, I don't feel there are a lot of decisions we don't make well. Bu ti do feel we have an opportunity to explain the "why" behind more of our decisions.

We need to consider that this is a different world than prior to March 2020. We are trying to be the world's most caring company, yet we're not taking into consideration the health and well-being of our Staff.
What work is important right now (how to appropriately prioritize)
with ever changing news with companies allowing remote work considering this as an option for staff retention

The structure of the work. While we seem to restructure often, there are pockets of the organization that still operate inefficiently. I think there is a need for broad organizational effectiveness support.

Creating inequities in talent selection decisions and internal staff mobility - certain departments seem to have many more in-role promotions and internal staff mobility - gig assignments are only possible for those staff that have capacity in their current roles. staff that are already overextended for time are now doubly disadvantaged in their inability to take on gig assignments or other opportunities for visibility

I have experienced many non-field facing decisions made based on personal perspectives not taking internal or external data insights into consideration.  By doing so, decisions change very quickly sometimes when we are close to execution.  I would suggest keeping what we are trying to solve for in mind as we make decisions and identifying what data can support us in the decision making and in mitigating risk. To ensure successful outcomes, I suggest we stay close to the evidences of results accomplished and adjust quickly if necessary.
decisions that require tradeoffs in our "triple win" (eg: tell our Operators at RPMs to take care of themselves while sharing the most ambitious Org plan they've ever seen)
Decisions that would be hard to "undo"
Headcount decisions - how many to allocate to depts, when to hire vs develop vs outsource
Decisions related to People policy, and generally getting work done.  There are significant overlaps of responsibility and accountability in verticals and also horizontally across the business.
Its apparent that DEI is an area of the business that needs more attention and tons more grace. Some Staff are not clear on the DEI strategy and it's expected outcomes.
Being out during the pandemic doesn't lend cause towards any improvement.  CFA, Inc. handled and continues to handle the business very well.
People-related decisions that are difficult, such as dealing with performance issues.
Decisions where we attempt to align and get buy-in from all stakeholders before beginning work
Flexible future, trust people to come as they need.  The perceived requirement of 10 days a month shows that trust is low in Staff to use good judgement.

Staff systems decisions and processes need to be improved.  With Service Gateway there are so many forms that I cannot find anything.  We should do the same process improvement work for our Staff processes.

Leadership: If the decisions being made at the planning level correctly, then Leadership will be able to make and share decision down to their org more easily and clearly.  Because of misalignments that happen at the planning level, Staff are often impacted by slow and/or changing decision making which then impacts their ability and capacity to deliver on work timely or within budget and it directly impacts the Staff experience (those who are recipients of the work).

Allow for more white space.  Have meetings start at 10 minutes after the hour. This will allow some white space to process from meeting to meeting. Educate others on what should be a meeting or could be answered via email.   This is an important item to address as we go back to in-person.  We are used to back-to-back meetings working virtually.  How will this work in person?  Will we be late to every meeting because there is no margin to move from meeting to meeting?
Balancing the show of care with entitlement. Chick-fil-A is amazing and we are blessed but it appears at times people lose sight of our blessings.

Headcount Decisions - new work pops up some times that can use an additional headcount. However, because headcount is planned annual, it can take time to get this headcount or this 'trading game' has to happen. This can prevent for from taking off or it causes in over work of some Staff members until the headcount is approved.
Internal process changes for efficiency - we are stakeholder heavy and too nice to "own" authority over a decision without getting everyone else's buy in
Decisions between different teams. If there is a potential issue that effects multiple teams the decision making process to decide who does what work can get very messy.
Does every decision fully need a spirit shared-ownership with operator community?
Consistency between departments and clear messages organizationally.

Decisions on how work teams are formed and how they are to go about the work that has been assigned to them.  There is an abundance of redundant work going on by different teams around the organization that don't know similar or related work is being done by another team.

Use of debt - With cheap financing options available, why wouldn't CFA pursue external debt financing to expand its distribution centers real estate strategy.  Funding this with internal cash flow limits other, higher growth options.  Using cash flow to fund low ROI projects seems irresponsible to shareholders in this rapidly changing and critical time for creating the infrastructure needed to affect necessary change and customer demand.
Selection decisions - both staff and Operators

Strategy - I love that we have a three year strategy. I think we need to be careful that all of the "thinking and planning" doesn't only exist at the executive level. We need all leaders to be frequently planning and strategizing by what's happening in the marketplace.

Execution of high-level decisions: Flexible future is a great framework, but the execution lands on people leaders.  If we want to be flexible one week, but then a member of the team will need to fly in on their own dollar then ultimately it is up to the people leader to enforce this decision.

I think that we need to increase our focus on how the decisions we make will impact the Customer in the long run. We have focused a lot on Operators recently, which is very important and appropriate! However, I do think that we do not want to lose sight of what is important to our Customers.
Decisions are often made to move forward with tactics/solutions without thoroughly understanding the problem.

In order to sometime appease external pressure and in an effort to maintain a positive brand image, Chick-fil-A leadership sometimes can refrain from taking a stand on governmental policies that there workforce don't agree with (extended COVID protocols for example).
Implementing future-proofing the brand processes. A lot of conversations are had about this topic but little is actually accomplished
We need to improve how fast we make innovative decisions. We are afraid of risk,and dont want to lead when it comes to moving into the future. ie. drone delivery, robots, etc
Facial hair was a decision that took a long time (3 years?) due to personal preferences of certain people.  It was not a data driven decision.
Identify what decisions need high collaboration and buy-in.
The organization structure and way people are promoted is going to eventually undermine trust in the EC.
Inclusivity and treating people like adults - breaking down perceptions and allowing people to dress for their day.
Ownership of decision making is an area we could improve our decision making.  We often "decide" who is going to decide but we do not follow through.  I'm hesitant to give a specific example.
We could be better at customer research and understanding what customers want before testing solutions that are more beneficial to the business.
Improvement is needed to continue and not lose culture.

Not shying away from who we are. Being bold when it comes to the world. That's what the Lord has called us to do. He is the reason we have been blessed beyond measure and we don't need to but him on the back burner.
Decisions that involve people moving around - especially to a role they have not expressed interest in - should include the individual in the decision making process.
Who has the decision and who needs to be involved in a decision.
The speed at which decisions are made
2. I wish I could come up with a 2nd example. I've been with the company about six weeks.
Chick-fil-A sometimes takes too long to make marketing decisions and falls behind trends (ex: e-commerce)
D,E & I work seems to be slow to move.
Headcount for new positions is always for upper levels, when in reality is we need more lower level positions to support the work.
Branding - we are often too humble and should be more confident in putting our name front and center in our marketing efforts.
DE&I decisions have taken awhile to be made

Reporting structure to the point where we don't have so many people leaders when we need more staff involved in the work.  In many cases there are people leaders leading only two people.  Need broader scope with fewer people leaders.
People managers -- some are much better at managing projects vs people

We promote young leaders to do jobs and lead people that haven't been developed enough to do it well. I've seen in happen one too many times - we take a young person who is a great project manager and expect them to manage people well. Then we are surprised when they don't and wonder why dissatisfaction of employees goes down.
People leadership. We often still confuse great project leaders as good people leaders.  Great work should not equal leading people.
Decision around goal setting and what is most important - we have a scope issue

When to cross the Operator Agreement lines- Employer Branding, and really the War for Talent is something that we could have been in front of a little more, but overemphasizing the Team Member being the Operator's employee kept Inc from stepping in sooner to support Operators in this area of the business.
Accountability decisions with partners specifically external ones. Being clear with feedback, even if it is constructive criticism, is kinder than avoiding the topic.

Operator DEI training and accountability for public facing staff and owners operating our businesses. Staff often hear about Operator?s actions.  Lack of required training and for our most visible leaders that interact with guests daily and lack of accountability when their actions are inappropriate has consequences.
New bodies of work being stood up and not really embraced across organization...Little Blue Menu was an exception.

I think the new leveling process has helped a lot with evening the playing field but still feel like sometimes it can feel unfair or inequitable. It sometimes feels like certain teams or individuals have favor when it comes to promotions and level changes, and those who don't complain and work quietly without complaint focused on the work, often times don't get advocated for, but those who push and complain about their level (instead of just doing their work well and humbly) sometimes get re-leveled. I think it'd be beneficial to have almost an "audit" from HR to revaluate each team and the levels ensuring all teams are equally leveled as it can feel like some teams are under represented while other teams are leveled higher across their people for the same amount/type of work on another team.
Allowing us to support the corporate purpose without being timid of things like prayer in departmental meetings.
Decisions involving Operator input (and knowing how to weigh those perspectives vs other opinions and ideas)

Assign or make clear that there is ONE leader to manage bodies of work and discuss direction of that work. There are too many chefs in the kitchen for certain bodies of work that does not allow for swift decision making or execution of work.
Getting better at this, but continued efforts to help staff understand the why behind a decision.
Letting people who did the work represent themselves instead of their leaders represent them when it comes to budget and headcount or project decisions from leadership.
do whatever it takes to advance the removal of foam cups from Chain
Decisions with no clear owner or cross-functional in nature

Decisions on moving people around in the organization.  Who has input into the decision?  How are employee's preferences taken into account?  How do decisions made at the EC level tie into the overall picture of talent management at CFA?
responding faster when it comes to external public responses (such as social injustices, etc.)
Rotation of senior leadership for many departments is much too frequent and can prevent some staff from forming strong relationships with them
While DTT improves tools and technology it would be great to have a standard set of tools and ongoing training and communications around these options.
Decisions that relate to how to grow efficiently for both the support center and Operators.

to give freedom to and acknowledge individuality among staff regarding beliefs and convictions - not everyone feels the same and has the same perspective when it comes to topics like vaccines, BLM, etc.
New Product Development needs to be faster
Decisions on when to end or give up on projects and re-deploy resources elsewhere
Decision making without or with limited consensus.  Getting to 100% agreement or consensus on a decision takes a lot of time.
Hiring candidates with years of unrelated experience over candidates with relevant skills and less experience.
Old ideas are built-on as there is a large amount of group think within our culture

Rhetoric or policies that very egregiously divide the workforce:  i.e., masking up the unvaccinated while the vaccinated have a different set of rules.   This is an extremely easy visual way to divide up the workforce... and it's not good.  Any visuals that even remotely feel like wearing a Scarlet letter, or a Yellow Star need to be taken VERY seriously.
Diverse leadership opportunities and career path options.
We make decisions by committee. Often this works to our advantage, other times it means our team lack trust or autonomy.

Tough conversations/decisions with Operators - we often do not have the courage to say hard things when we think Operators don't want to hear them; we often do not empower staff when the perception is they are not serving Operators well (ex: answer your phone and emails regardless of the opportunity cost of that availability)
When it comes to making a decision at a lower team level - sometime it feels like everyone has to agree before moving forward.
Our website- there is very little clarity into how teams can become a priority with CDX. We need to be able to turn around web redesigns or update/edit pages beyond simple text quickly.

Holding leaders accountable for feedback - I've had multiple leaders at this point and all have fallen short on providing feedback outside of the fact that I'm doing a good job. It's hard for me to understand the areas where I need improvement.

Cross-functional work. Decision rights are not clear, too many competing priorities, not enough allocation of time to do great work. Lack of processes to move faster. We are just getting things done but not with excellent thinking. Restaurants are paying the price.

We are under resourced in some areas of the business with Talent. Project dollars get approved yet the headcount to support the same project does not. Staff are being asked to do more and more, and go faster and faster. We are doing our best, but it's beginning to feel like changing a flat tire while driving down the road.
Solutions that are ready to test or launch - having a consistent approach across teams that do similar work.

Again, with technology. Of course, we need to use the most effective and efficient programs of the day. But we spend so much time training and implementing new, new, new...there is a significant amount of time wasted trying to access all the avenues of Help. [WorkDay alone has videos to watch, Walk Me Through, Pathway, Reference charts and guides to review, Degreed programs and time to read through all that versus a quick phone call to a qualified person seems to have gone away. The thought that it is automated puts it on the user to take alot of learning time versus someone trained to give quicker answers. And then there are emails and the constant reference to use Service Gateway which is time consuming to wait for a response, sometimes days to weeks when an urgent response is need. Calling is discouraged and also many times the person in Help is having to "Google it" versus being trained to have the answers it seems].
New product rollout decisions could be more strategic if we balanced operational needs/Voice of Operator with Customer needs better.
There continues to be a need for more flexibility at the restaurant level for unique business opportunities.
Investment decision in capabilities that are for upkeep vs. business/sales generation.
Decisions around internal role movement. Example, I had to interview over 10 hours for a internal position that was a level down from where I currently was.
Focusing on Operations and supply over the needs/quality served to the guest

decisions that affect our appearance (ex. not requiring ties, facial hair for men). coming back to work after COVID is going to be difficult for a lot of people because we've all forgotten how to look to be "on" at work. It would be nice if more relaxed dress code were offered (ex. nice jeans with no holes) on some/all days to encourage people to actually be in the office. You can look really nice & approachable in jeans.

Chick-fil-A needs to improve on their decisions of who to promote.  Although we have promoted DE&I and how that needs to be embraced throughout the organization, it's only slowly having an impact on the lower levels of the organization.  As you take a look at senior levels of leadership, there's very little diversity.  Specific people groups (within the broader minority group) are more likely to be noticed and promoted than others.
The space to innovate without the strict construct of certain timelines.
Building a cohesive system and tools to facilitate the execution of work and remove drag from the process.
HR process are slow... posting open positions, hiring, getting promotions approved.
restaurant design, especially the kitchen, for growth and changing customer trends like delivery and mobile ordering
department organizational decisions - feels like it can take forever for the right people to be in the right place

I know the business is growing and the Company is making an effort not to fall behind on the staff needed to support those demands, however, it does appear as though we are growing the Staff count much higher than the locations. Yes the business itself seems to be growing quickly and the demands from each location is ever increasing but not sure it justifies the current pace of staff count.

We should find ways to run the third shift in the restaurant, the equipment is not generating profit at night. Can we develop decentralized factories using the restaurants at night to produce frozen products and sell them to local grocery stores?
When solutions are "put on the shelf" by the time the organization is ready for them they will be out of date requiring teams to re-work.

2022 PLANNING was a mess, from the perspective of project owners/intake participants.   Dates, expectations, roles were unclear.  The communication was like a game of telephone - different planning leads heard different things and relayed conflicting messages to their teams.  There was a lot of wasted time between departments trying to figure out who should input a project, determining if it was already covered elsewhere, and trying to stuff projects into buckets that might have money (strategic bets or marketplace relevance fund).  We can do better with Planning!!!
Proactive communication to the field about innovation work (so that Operators can understand and trust that we are working on the right topics for the future)
Consider how staff can be intentional about connecting and assisting Operators to further develop relationships and partnerships.

Ensuring talent is aligned with most critical work.  It seems a lot of Staff are overloaded but others may have capacity.  For several years we've talked about putting resources where they add the most value to the business but we still have work to do to ensure that's happening.
Vendor partner selection and maintenance (e.g., we are not diverse enough and do not leverage RFPs enough)
Decisions on DEI. We are moving slowly in this department. If we want to reach more guest internationally we need to improve in this area.
Decisions that require speed under control.
Decisions about whether to buy or build technology.
Chick-fil-A needs to improve how decisions around Restaurant simplification. There are a lot of difficult products and procedures for Team Members.
I notice a lot of overlap in roles and positions as far as what people are working on, so I would say decisions around headcount and work could be improved upon.

On occasion we do need to manage someone's career out of CFA and that takes way too long.  Creates drag for teams, morale issues, inability to hire more qualified talent, and a people leader challenge.
We can get better identifying decision makers and allowing those decision makers to act.  Sometimes we take too long when we are making decisions.
It would be helpful to have greater clarity on how initiatives are prioritized across the organization.

CFA needs to improve decisions about prioritization.  While our leadership makes high level decisions about priorities and focus, that messaging does not get supported by those actually managing work streams.  There is no follow through or accountability from leaders when their teams put higher priorities over their work in conflict with organizational priorities.  It seems like every department and sub department is only looking out for their own priorities as opposed to the greater organizational priorities or focus areas.
Strategic decisions: often unclear who owns decisions and guidance isn't well communicated or transparency is inconsistent

When to engage contractors. How long will CFA be satisfied with that? What kind of stewardship is that? That is not a deal most of us would strike in our personal lives, and we have been entrusted with much more at Chick-fil-A to stewards than we have been entrusted with personally.

Decisions to disproportionately invest resources in certain innovation projects that cannot bring sufficient ROI for Operators or the brand ("blank check" for projects like Canadian expansion or Little Blue Menu).
CFA needs to do more to inform the business on different roles of each group and how they support each other to ultimately support Operators and Team Members.
Promotion and headcount approval processes -- feel the lack of clarity and opportunity could be a competitive disadvantage
Holding relocating Operators accountable for poor restaurant conditions
Increase in head count to support the tremendous growth of the business.

We are not doing a great job with transparency around promotions.  It very much feels like people are tapped without much process or consistent rationale.  Within departments we need to do a better job of defining what leads to promotion opportunities, and across the Company we desperately need an entire releveling to bring more equity from one division to another.
Adding internal resources/team members can be a lengthy process, which can be detrimental in today's tight labor market.
Decisions regarding recruitment and retention of minority Operators
Non-Operator-facing decisions - when a direct Operator outcome is not obvious, but it?s still an important decision, sometimes we can be slow or flippant in the decision.

We need to be more enterprise-minded in our selections of technology solutions. I understand that each department enjoys a certain amount of autonomy, but when these project involve touching a restaurant, we really need everyone enterprise-wide to have visibility into all projects occurring or being considered at each restaurant so we don't run into duplication of efforts or issues with Landlords or third parties. So often, legal is the team that uncovers these issues because we are engaged by multiple departments, but we don't often uncover the multiple projects until after a Landlord or third party is upset. Enterprise wide solutions (or at least enterprise compatible) are really critical.
So many meetings about non-substantive matters
Decisions where the sustainability of the workload is questionable.

The speed, effectiveness, and individuality of Operator response to the pandemic was a good reminder that the Operator relationship is our key differentiator. CFA and CFA leadership needs to publicly and explicitly state its position towards the LBGTQ+ community. The ambiguity of the statements made to date and lack of follow through make it a barrier for some great people to join the CFA family; in addition, this makes certain current employees feel like they cannot be their true authentic selves at work which is a major shortcoming of our culture of care.

While I will sing the praises of Chick-fil-A's decision making in the sense that we are exceptionally analytical and really take the time to evaluate the impact of a decision, see the short and long term effects of it, and weigh risks thoroughly, that obviously can slow some decisions. 95% of the time, I still think that is the right thing to do and not being impulsive has probably saved Chick-fil-A a hundred times over in ways we will never even know. However, there also needs to be a little more room to be reactive to our environment and inject fun and spontaneity into the brand. I was lucky enough to witness an incredible example of this this year when Joe Saracino and Sara Storck led the 50/50 beverage campaign for the NBA Finals celebration. They saw an incredible marketing and customer experience opportunity to capitalize on, and were able to rally a large team to make it happen in less than two days. While the vast majority of decisions can't be made that way, and there were many who were hesitant stating there could be some backfire from moving so quickly, Joe said something to the effect of "I hear the concerns, but in thinking through how incredibly minor the risks are for this type of short term offer we're going to do this bc it's a chance to really quickly inject some fun into Chick-fil-A." It was personally the most fun I have had working on something here in years, and the long day and quick agility was reinvigorating. I think we need to find more opportunities for that instead of planning and evaluating every decision to death, when the risk level allows it.
Departments outside of DTT building technical solutions that are not supportable because DTT doesn't have bandwidth. This just creates a support nightmare long term.

We need to improve decisions about Staff roles. And now that we turn over non-managed service provider contractors every year, this causes even more headaches with turnover, ramp up time, and knowledge sharing.

Showing care and valuing opinions of ALL staff, not just the few. Many staff sit in the quiet feeling uncared for and that their feelings and opinions are not valued when they don't fully match the company talking point.
